article:
# Carl Friedrich Gauss

Carl Friedrich Gauss (1777-1855) was a German mathematician and physicist who is widely regarded as one of the most influential mathematicians in history. His contributions to various fields, including number theory, algebra, geometry, and astronomy, have had a lasting impact on the development of mathematics and science.

# Biography

## Youth and education

Gauss was born on April 30, 1777, in Braunschweig, Germany, to a poor family. His father was a bricklayer and a gardener, and his mother was an illiterate woman who had a significant influence on Gauss's early education. Gauss's exceptional mathematical abilities were recognized at an early age, and he began attending the local elementary school at the age of three. In 1788, he entered the Martino-Katharineum, a prestigious secondary school in Braunschweig, where he excelled in mathematics and languages.

## Private scholar

After completing his secondary education, Gauss's parents wanted him to become a merchant, but Gauss's interests lay in mathematics. In 1795, he began studying mathematics at the University of Göttingen, where he was heavily influenced by the works of Leonhard Euler and Joseph-Louis Lagrange. However, Gauss did not attend classes regularly, preferring to study on his own. During this period, he made significant contributions to number theory, including the discovery of the prime number theorem.

## Professor in Göttingen

In 1807, Gauss was appointed as the director of the astronomical observatory at the University of Göttingen, a position he held until his death. He became a professor of astronomy and mathematics in 1810 and was granted a lifetime appointment in 1824. During his tenure, Gauss made significant contributions to astronomy, including the discovery of the asteroid Ceres and the development of a new method for calculating orbits.

## Gauss's brain

After Gauss's death, his brain was preserved and studied by the neurologist Rudolf Wagner, who discovered that Gauss's brain was unusual in several respects. The brain was found to have a highly developed cerebral cortex, which is responsible for higher-order thinking, and an unusually high number of glial cells, which provide support and protection to neurons. These findings have been interpreted as evidence of Gauss's exceptional cognitive abilities.

## Family

Gauss married Johanna Osthoff in 1805, and they had two sons, Joseph and Wilhelm. After Johanna's death in 1809, Gauss married Minna Waldeck in 1810, and they had three children together. Gauss's family life was marked by tragedy, including the death of his first wife and his daughter, who died in infancy.

## Personality

### Scholar

Gauss was known for his intense focus and dedication to his work. He was a perfectionist who was deeply committed to his research and was willing to spend years working on a single problem. Gauss was also known for his exceptional memory and his ability to perform complex calculations in his head.

### Private man

Despite his fame and reputation, Gauss was a private person who preferred to avoid publicity. He was known to be humble and unassuming, and he rarely sought to draw attention to himself. Gauss was also a kind and generous person who was deeply committed to his family and friends.

# Scientific work

## Algebra and number theory

### Fundamental theorem of algebra

Gauss's most famous contribution to algebra is the fundamental theorem of algebra, which states that every polynomial equation has at least one complex root. This theorem, which was first proved by Gauss in 1799, has far-reaching implications for many areas of mathematics and science.

### Disquisitiones Arithmeticae

Gauss's magnum opus is the Disquisitiones Arithmeticae, a comprehensive treatise on number theory that was published in 1801. This work, which covers topics such as congruences, quadratic forms, and the theory of numbers, is considered one of the greatest works of mathematics ever written.

### Further investigations

Gauss made many other significant contributions to algebra and number theory, including the development of the theory of elliptic curves and the discovery of the prime number theorem. He also worked on the theory of modular forms and the study of the distribution of prime numbers.

## Analysis

### Numeric analysis

Gauss made significant contributions to the field of numeric analysis, including the development of the method of least squares and the invention of the Gaussian distribution. He also worked on the theory of interpolation and the study of the convergence of series.

## Chronology

Gauss's work on chronology, which is the study of the measurement of time, led to the development of a new method for calculating the date of Easter. This method, which is still used today, is based on the lunar cycle and the solar year.

## Astronomy

Gauss made many significant contributions to astronomy, including the discovery of the asteroid Ceres and the development of a new method for calculating orbits. He also worked on the study of the motion of the planets and the theory of the tides.

## Theory of errors

Gauss's work on the theory of errors, which is the study of the measurement of uncertainty, led to the development of the Gaussian distribution. This distribution, which is also known as the bell curve, is a fundamental concept in statistics and is used to model many types of data.

## Arc measurement and geodetic survey

Gauss made significant contributions to the field of geodesy, including the development of a new method for measuring the arc of a meridian. He also worked on the study of the shape of the Earth and the theory of the tides.

## Differential geometry

Gauss's work on differential geometry, which is the study of the properties of curves and surfaces, led to the development of the Gaussian curvature. This concept, which is a measure of the curvature of a surface, is a fundamental concept in mathematics and physics.

Gauss's work on non-Euclidean geometry, which is the study of geometries that are not based on the principles of Euclid, led to the development of the theory of hyperbolic geometry. This theory, which is a fundamental concept in mathematics and physics, is used to model many types of spaces.

Gauss's work on topology, which is the study of the properties of shapes and spaces, led to the development of the theory of knots and links. This theory, which is a fundamental concept in mathematics and physics, is used to model many types of spaces.

Gauss's work on geomagnetism, which is the study of the Earth's magnetic field, led to the development of a new method for measuring the strength of the magnetic field. He also worked on the study of the variation of the magnetic field over time.

Gauss's work on electromagnetism, which is the study of the interaction between electric and magnetic fields, led to the development of the theory of the electromagnetic field. This theory, which is a fundamental concept in physics, is used to model many types of phenomena.

Gauss's work on potential theory, which is the study of the properties of gravitational and electric fields, led to the development of the theory of the gravitational potential. This theory, which is a fundamental concept in physics, is used to model many types of phenomena.

Lisa Marie Presley

Lisa Marie Presley (February 1, 1968 – January 12, 2023) was an American singer-songwriter and heiress to the estate of her father, Elvis Presley. Born into a musical family, Lisa Marie's life was marked by her famous heritage, as well as her own struggles and successes in the music industry.

# Early life

Lisa Marie Presley was born on February 1, 1968, at Baptist Memorial Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, to Elvis Presley and his wife Priscilla Presley. She was the only child of the couple and spent her early years living at the Presley family home, Graceland. After her parents' divorce in 1973, Lisa Marie lived with her mother in Los Angeles, but spent summers with her father in Memphis.

Lisa Marie's early life was marked by her famous father's struggles with addiction and weight gain. She has spoken publicly about the difficulties of growing up with a famous parent, including the constant media attention and the emotional challenges of dealing with her father's health issues. Despite these challenges, Lisa Marie has said that her father was a loving and supportive parent, and that she cherished the time they spent together.

# Career

## 2003–2005: To Whom It May Concern

Lisa Marie Presley released her debut album, "To Whom It May Concern", in 2003. The album was a commercial success, debuting at number 5 on the US Billboard 200 chart and selling over 500,000 copies in the United States. The album spawned two singles, "Lights Out" and "Sinking In", both of which received moderate airplay on adult contemporary radio.

The album received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising Lisa Marie's vocal talent and songwriting skills. However, some critics noted that the album's production was overly polished and that the songs lacked a clear direction.

## 2005–2012: Now What and further singles

Lisa Marie Presley's second album, "Now What", was released in 2005. The album was less commercially successful than her debut, but still received positive reviews from critics. The album spawned two singles, "Dirty Laundry" and "Idiot", both of which received moderate airplay on adult contemporary radio.

In 2010, Lisa Marie Presley released a single, "You Ain't Seen Nothing Yet", which was a cover of a song by her father's friend and fellow musician, Carl Perkins. The single received moderate airplay on country radio.

## 2012–2018: Storm & Grace and final releases

Lisa Marie Presley's third album, "Storm & Grace", was released in 2012. The album was a more stripped-down and rootsy effort than her previous work, and received positive reviews from critics. The album spawned two singles, "You Ain't Seen Nothing Yet" (a re-release of the 2010 single) and "I Love You Because".

In 2014, Lisa Marie Presley released a single, "Over Me", which was a cover of a song by her father's friend and fellow musician, Willie Nelson.

## Memoir

In 2023, Lisa Marie Presley announced that she was working on a memoir, which would detail her life and career. However, the memoir was not completed before her death.

# Charity work and humanitarian efforts

## Grammy Foundation

Lisa Marie Presley was a long-time supporter of the Grammy Foundation, a non-profit organization that supports music education and advocacy programs. She served on the organization's board of directors and participated in several fundraising events.

# Awards and honors

Lisa Marie Presley received several awards and honors throughout her career, including a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and a Grammy nomination for Best Female Rock Vocal Performance.

# Personal life

## Marriages and divorces

* Michael Jackson (married 1994-1996)
* Nicolas Cage (married 2002-2004)
* Michael Lockwood (married 2006-2021)

## Scientology

Lisa Marie Presley was a longtime member of the Church of Scientology, but left the organization in 2014.

# Elvis Presley estate

Lisa Marie Presley inherited her father's estate, including Graceland, after his death in 1977. She managed the estate and oversaw several business ventures, including the Elvis Presley Enterprises company.

## "Elvis Through His Daughter's Eyes" exhibit

In 2012, Lisa Marie Presley curated an exhibit at Graceland called "Elvis Through His Daughter's Eyes", which featured personal artifacts and memorabilia from her father's life and career.

## Aircraft Lisa Marie

Lisa Marie Presley owned a private jet, the "Lisa Marie", which was named after her. The plane was a Convair 880, and was previously owned by her father.

Lisa Marie Presley died on January 12, 2023, at the age of 54. The cause of death was not immediately disclosed.

article:
Donald Trump

Donald John Trump is the 45th President of the United States, serving from 2017 to 2021. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality. Trump was born on June 14, 1946, in Queens, New York, to Mary Anne MacLeod and Frederick Christ Trump. He is the fourth of five children.

# Personal life

## Early life

Trump grew up in Jamaica, Queens, and attended the New York Military Academy. He then studied at Fordham University for two years before transferring to the University of Pennsylvania, where he graduated with a degree in economics in 1968.

## Family

Trump's family has been involved in real estate development for several generations. His father, Frederick, was a successful real estate developer in New York City. Trump's mother, Mary Anne, was a homemaker and later became a philanthropist. Trump has five children: three with his first wife, Ivana Trump; one with his second wife, Marla Maples; and one with his third wife, Melania Trump. His children are Donald Jr., Ivanka, Eric, Tiffany, and Barron.

## Religion

Trump was raised as a Presbyterian and attended the First Presbyterian Church in Jamaica, Queens, as a child. In 2016, he stated that he was a Christian and that his favorite biblical book was the Old Testament.

## Health habits

Trump's health has been a subject of interest and controversy. In 2016, his doctor released a letter stating that Trump was in "excellent physical health" and that his medical tests were "astonishingly good." However, some medical experts have questioned the accuracy of the letter.

## Wealth

Trump's wealth has been estimated to be around $3.1 billion, according to Forbes. His net worth comes from a variety of sources, including his real estate empire, his television shows, and his licensing deals.

# Business career

## Real estate

Trump's real estate career began in the 1970s, when he joined his father's company, the Trump Organization. In the 1980s, he began to develop his own properties, including the Trump Tower in Manhattan and the Trump Plaza in Atlantic City.

### Manhattan and Chicago developments

Trump developed several high-end properties in Manhattan, including the Trump Tower, Trump Park Avenue, and Trump International Hotel and Tower. He also developed the Trump International Hotel and Tower in Chicago.

### Atlantic City casinos

Trump developed several casinos in Atlantic City, including the Trump Taj Mahal, the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, and the Trump Marina. However, his casinos struggled financially, and he was forced to declare bankruptcy several times.

### Clubs

Trump also developed several golf clubs and resorts, including the Trump National Doral in Miami and the Trump Turnberry in Scotland.

## Licensing of the Trump brand

Trump has licensed his brand to several companies, including clothing manufacturers, home decor companies, and even a line of steaks.

## Side ventures

### Trump University

Trump University was a for-profit business school that Trump founded in 2005. The school offered courses in real estate investing, entrepreneurship, and other subjects. However, the school was shut down in 2010 after several lawsuits were filed against it.

## Foundation

The Donald J. Trump Foundation was a charitable organization founded by Trump in 1987. The foundation donated to several charities, including the Children's Aid Society and the American Red Cross. However, the foundation was shut down in 2018 after it was revealed that Trump had used the foundation's funds to pay off his personal debts.

## Legal affairs and bankruptcies

Trump has been involved in several lawsuits and bankruptcies throughout his career. In 1990, he filed for bankruptcy after his Taj Mahal casino struggled financially. He filed for bankruptcy again in 2004 after his Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts company struggled.

# Media career

## Books

Trump has written several bestselling books, including "The Art of the Deal" and "Great Again: How to Fix Our Crippled America."

## Film and television

Trump has appeared in several films and television shows, including "Home Alone 2: Lost in New York," "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and "The Apprentice."

# Political career

## Presidential campaigns (2000–2016)

Trump first considered running for president in 2000, but he ultimately decided not to run. He considered running again in 2012, but he ultimately endorsed Mitt Romney.

### 2016 presidential campaign

Trump announced his candidacy for president in June 2015. He won the Republican primary in May 2016 and went on to win the general election in November.

#### Campaign rhetoric and political positions

Trump's campaign was marked by controversy and divisive rhetoric. He advocated for a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, a ban on Muslim immigration, and a repeal of the Affordable Care Act.

#### Financial disclosures

Trump refused to release his tax returns during the campaign, citing an ongoing audit. However, he did release a financial disclosure form that showed he had earned $362 million in 2015.

#### Election to the presidency

Trump won the presidential election on November 8, 2016, defeating Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. He won 304 electoral votes to Clinton's 227.

# Presidency (2017–2021)

## Early actions

Trump took several executive actions in his first few days in office, including withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and reinstating the Mexico City policy.

## Conflicts of interest

Trump faced several conflicts of interest as president, including his ownership of the Trump Organization and his children's involvement in the business.

## Domestic policy

### Economy

Trump signed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act in 2017, which lowered corporate tax rates and individual tax rates. He also imposed tariffs on several countries, including China and Canada.

### Climate change, environment, and energy

Trump withdrew from the Paris Climate Agreement in 2017 and rolled back several environmental regulations. He also promoted the use of fossil fuels and signed an executive order to promote offshore drilling.

### Deregulation

Trump signed an executive order in 2017 to reduce regulatory burdens on businesses. He also rolled back several financial regulations, including the Dodd-Frank Act.

### Health care

Trump attempted to repeal the Affordable Care Act several times, but he was unsuccessful. He did, however, sign an executive order to expand short-term health insurance plans.

### Social issues

Trump signed an executive order in 2017 to ban transgender individuals from serving in the military. He also rolled back several LGBTQ+ protections.

## Pardons and commutations

Trump granted several pardons and commutations during his presidency, including a pardon for former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio.

## Immigration

### Travel ban

Trump signed an executive order in 2017 to ban travel from several predominantly Muslim countries. The ban was challenged in court, but it was ultimately upheld by the Supreme Court.

### Family separation at the border

Trump's administration implemented a policy of separating families at the border in 2018. The policy was widely criticized, and it was eventually reversed.

### Trump wall and government shutdown

Trump demanded funding for a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border in 2018, leading to a government shutdown. The shutdown lasted for 35 days, but Trump ultimately signed a bill to reopen the government without funding for the wall.

## Foreign policy

### Trade

Trump imposed tariffs on several countries, including China and Canada. He also renegotiated several trade agreements, including NAFTA.

### Russia

Trump's administration was marked by controversy over its ties to Russia. Trump met with Russian President Vladimir Putin several times, and he was criticized for his handling of the relationship.

### China

Trump imposed tariffs on China in 2018, leading to a trade war. He also met with Chinese President Xi Jinping several times.

### North Korea

Trump met with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un several times, including a summit in Singapore in 2018.

### Afghanistan

Trump announced a troop withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2019, but he eventually reversed the decision.

### Israel

Trump recognized Jerusalem as Israel's capital in 2017, leading to widespread criticism. He also moved the U.S. embassy to Jerusalem.

### Saudi Arabia

Trump's administration was criticized for its handling of the relationship with Saudi Arabia, including the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

### Syria

Trump announced a troop withdrawal from Syria in 2019, but he eventually reversed the decision.

### Iran

Trump withdrew from the Iran nuclear deal in 2018 and imposed sanctions on the country.

## Personnel

Trump had a high turnover rate in his administration, with several high-profile firings and resignations.

## Judiciary

Trump nominated two Supreme Court justices during his presidency, including Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh.

## COVID-19 pandemic

### Initial response

Trump's administration was criticized for its initial response to the pandemic, including a lack of testing and a slow rollout of personal protective equipment.

### White House Coronavirus Task Force

Trump established the White House Coronavirus Task Force in January 2020, led by Vice President Mike Pence.

### World Health Organization

Trump withdrew from the World Health Organization in 2020, citing its handling of the pandemic.

### Pressure to abandon pandemic mitigation measures

Trump faced pressure from some of his supporters to abandon pandemic mitigation measures, including mask mandates and social distancing.

### Political pressure on health agencies

Trump's administration was accused of putting political pressure on health agencies, including the CDC and the FDA.

### Outbreak at the White House

An outbreak of COVID-19 occurred at the White House in October 2020, including infections of Trump and several of his staff.

### Effects on the 2020 presidential campaign

The pandemic had a significant impact on the 2020 presidential campaign, including a shift to virtual events and a focus on pandemic response.

## Investigations

### Russian election interference

Trump's administration was investigated for its ties to Russia and potential interference in the 2016 election.

### FBI Crossfire Hurricane and 2017 counterintelligence investigations

The FBI launched an investigation into Trump's campaign in 2016, known as Crossfire Hurricane.

### Mueller investigation

Special Counsel Robert Mueller was appointed in 2017 to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 election and potential obstruction of justice.

## First impeachment

### Impeachment trial in the Senate

Trump was impeached by the House of Representatives in December 2019 on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. He was acquitted by the Senate in February 2020.

## 2020 presidential campaign

Trump ran for re-election in 2020, facing several Democratic challengers. He ultimately lost the election to Joe Biden.

## 2020 presidential election

### False claims of voting fraud, attempt to prevent presidential transition

Trump made several false claims of voting fraud after the election and attempted to prevent the transition to the Biden administration.

### Concern about a possible coup attempt or military action

There were concerns about a possible coup attempt or military action by Trump after the election.

### January 6 Capitol attack

A violent attack on the U.S. Capitol occurred on January 6, 2021, in which Trump supporters attempted to overturn the election results.

### Second impeachment

Trump was impeached by the House of Representatives again in January 2021 on charges of inciting an insurrection. He was acquitted by the Senate in February 2021.

# Post-presidency (2021–present)

## Business activities

Trump has continued to be involved in his business empire since leaving office.

## Investigations, criminal indictments and convictions, civil lawsuits

### FBI investigations

The FBI has continued to investigate Trump and his associates since he left office.

### Criminal referral by the House January 6 Committee

The House January 6 Committee referred Trump to the Justice Department for potential prosecution.

### Federal and state criminal indictments

Trump has been indicted on several federal and state charges, including charges related to the January 6 Capitol attack.

### Criminal conviction in the 2016 campaign fraud case

Trump was convicted of campaign finance fraud in 2023.

### Civil judgments against Trump

Trump has faced several civil judgments since leaving office, including a judgment related to his business dealings in New York.

## 2024 presidential campaign

Trump announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election in November 2022.

# Public image

## Scholarly assessment and public approval surveys

Trump's presidency was widely criticized by scholars and the public.

## False or misleading statements

Trump made several false or misleading statements during his presidency, including claims about the size of his inauguration crowd and the effectiveness of his policies.

## Promotion of conspiracy theories

Trump promoted several conspiracy theories during his presidency, including claims about voter fraud and the Deep State.

## Incitement of violence

Trump was accused of inciting violence against his opponents, including journalists and protesters.

## Social media

Trump was active on social media during his presidency, including Twitter and Facebook.

## Relationship with the press

Trump had a contentious relationship with the press during his presidency, including several public feuds with journalists and media outlets.

## Racial views

Trump's racial views have been widely criticized, including his comments about Muslims, Mexicans, and African Americans.

## Misogyny and allegations of sexual misconduct

Trump has been accused of misogyny and sexual misconduct, including allegations of harassment and assault.

Trump has been the subject of several popular culture depictions, including Saturday Night Live and The Daily Show.

Jawan (film)
================

Jawan is an upcoming Indian Hindi-language action thriller film directed by Atlee and produced by Gauri Khan, under the banner of Red Chillies Entertainment. The film is set to be released in 2023 and stars Shah Rukh Khan in the lead role, marking his first collaboration with Atlee. The film's plot and cast have generated significant interest among fans and critics alike, making it one of the most anticipated releases of the year.

Plot
-----

The plot of Jawan revolves around a mysterious figure, played by Shah Rukh Khan, who is on a mission to uncover the truth behind a conspiracy that threatens the nation. As the story unfolds, the protagonist must use his wit, intelligence, and physical prowess to overcome obstacles and enemies. The film is expected to feature high-octane action sequences, suspenseful moments, and emotional drama, keeping the audience engaged and invested in the story.

* Shah Rukh Khan as the protagonist

* Yogi Babu as a supporting character

Production
------------

### Development

The development of Jawan began in 2020, when Atlee was approached by Gauri Khan to direct a film for Red Chillies Entertainment. Atlee, known for his work on films like Mersal and Bigil, was keen to collaborate with Shah Rukh Khan, who was impressed by the director's vision and script. The film's story and screenplay were written by Atlee, along with a team of writers, and the project was officially announced in 2021.

### Casting

The casting process for Jawan was a lengthy and meticulous one, with the filmmakers taking their time to find the right actors for each role. Shah Rukh Khan was the first actor to be cast, followed by Nayanthara, who was chosen for the female lead. Vijay Sethupathi was later cast as the main antagonist, while Priyamani, Sanya Malhotra, Sunil Grover, and Yogi Babu were added to the supporting cast.

### Filming

The principal photography for Jawan began in September 2021 and took place in various locations across India and abroad. The film's cinematography was handled by G.K. Vishnu, who worked closely with Atlee to capture the desired visual style and tone. The action sequences in the film were choreographed by stunt masters Anbariv and others.

### Post-production

The post-production work for Jawan began in early 2022, with the editing being handled by Ruben. The film's music and background score were composed by Anirudh Ravichander, who worked closely with Atlee to create the desired sound and atmosphere. The visual effects for the film were handled by a team of experts, led by Sreekar Prasad.

Themes and influences
----------------------

Jawan explores several themes, including patriotism, loyalty, and the struggle for justice. The film's storyline is influenced by real-life events and draws inspiration from various sources, including Indian history and mythology. The film's action sequences and stunts are inspired by Hollywood films, while the emotional drama and character development are rooted in Indian cinema.

Music
------

The music for Jawan was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, who is known for his work on films like Kabali and Petta. The film's soundtrack features several songs, including a patriotic anthem and a romantic ballad. The background score for the film was also composed by Anirudh, who worked closely with Atlee to create the desired atmosphere and tone.

Marketing
-----------

The marketing campaign for Jawan began in 2022, with the release of a teaser trailer that generated significant buzz and interest among fans. The film's promotional materials, including posters and social media posts, have been designed to create a sense of intrigue and suspense around the story and characters.

Release

### Theatrical

Jawan is set to be released in theaters in 2023, with the exact date yet to be announced. The film will be released in multiple languages, including Hindi, Tamil, and Telugu, and is expected to have a wide release across India and abroad.

### Distribution

### Home media

The home media rights for Jawan have been acquired by a leading streaming platform, which will release the film on its platform after its theatrical run. The film's DVD and Blu-ray rights have also been acquired by a leading home video distributor.

Reception
------------

### Box office

The box office prospects for Jawan are highly anticipated, with the film expected to perform well in India and abroad. The film's budget is estimated to be around ₹200 crore, and it is expected to recover its costs through a combination of theatrical and home media revenue.

### Critical response

The critical response to Jawan is expected to be positive, with the film's storyline, action sequences, and performances generating interest and praise from critics. The film's direction, cinematography, and music are also expected to be praised by critics.

Accolades
------------

The success of Jawan is expected to lead to a sequel or spin-off, with the film's storyline and characters providing ample opportunities for further exploration and development. The film's cast and crew are also expected to collaborate on future projects, with Atlee and Shah Rukh Khan reportedly discussing several ideas and scripts.

2023 Nashville School Shooting

On March 27, 2023, a mass shooting occurred at the Covenant School, a private Christian elementary school in Nashville, Tennessee. The shooting resulted in the deaths of six people, including three children, and left several others injured. The incident sparked widespread outrage and calls for stricter gun control laws.

# Background

The Covenant School is a private Christian elementary school located in the Green Hills neighborhood of Nashville, Tennessee. The school is part of the Covenant Presbyterian Church and serves students from preschool to sixth grade. The school has a strong reputation in the community for its academic excellence and commitment to Christian values.

In the months leading up to the shooting, the United States had experienced a series of mass shootings, including the 2022 Robb Elementary School shooting in Uvalde, Texas, which killed 19 children and two teachers. The incidents had reignited the national debate on gun control and school safety.

# Shooting

On the morning of March 27, 2023, a gunman entered the Covenant School through a side door. The shooter, later identified as Audrey Hale, was armed with two assault-style rifles and a handgun. Hale began firing shots in the school's hallways and classrooms, striking multiple victims.

The first 911 call was made at 10:13 a.m. local time, and police responded quickly to the scene. Officers from the Metro Nashville Police Department (MNPD) arrived within minutes and engaged the shooter. Hale was shot and killed by police at 10:27 a.m.

## Victims

Six people were killed in the shooting, including three children and three adults. The victims were identified as:

* Evelyn Dieckhaus, 9
* William Kinney, 9
* Hallie Scruggs, 9
* Cynthia Peak, 61, a substitute teacher
* Katherine Koonce, 60, the head of the school
* Mike Hill, 61, a custodian

article:
Liga 1 (Indonesia)
================

Liga 1 is the top professional football league in Indonesia. It was founded in 1994 and has since become one of the most popular sports leagues in the country. The league is contested by 18 clubs and operates on a system of promotion and relegation with Liga 2, the second tier of Indonesian football.

History
--------

### Origins

The origins of Liga 1 date back to 1979 when the Perserikatan, a semi-professional league, was established. However, the league was not well-organized, and it was eventually replaced by the Galatama, a more professional league, in 1982. The Galatama was the top league in Indonesia until 1994 when it was replaced by the Liga Indonesia.

### Foundation

The Liga Indonesia was founded in 1994 as the top professional league in Indonesia. The league was initially contested by 34 clubs, but it was later reduced to 28 clubs in 1995. The league was divided into two divisions, with the top division featuring 18 clubs and the second division featuring 10 clubs.

### Dualism

In the early 2000s, Indonesian football was plagued by dualism, with two rival leagues operating in the country. The Liga Indonesia was the official top league, but it was rivalled by the Indonesian Premier League (IPL), which was founded in 2011. The IPL was not recognized by the Football Association of Indonesia (PSSI), but it was supported by several top clubs.

### Government intervention and FIFA suspension

In 2015, the Indonesian government intervened in the dispute between the PSSI and the IPL, and the PSSI was eventually suspended by FIFA. The suspension was lifted in 2016, and the PSSI was reformed.

### Name change

In 2017, the Liga Indonesia was rebranded as Liga 1. The name change was made to make the league more attractive to fans and sponsors.

Competition format
------------------

### Competition

Liga 1 is contested by 18 clubs, with each club playing the others twice, once at home and once away. The team with the most points at the end of the season is crowned champion.

### Promotion and relegation

The bottom three clubs in Liga 1 are relegated to Liga 2, while the top three clubs in Liga 2 are promoted to Liga 1.

### Video assistant referee

Liga 1 has used video assistant referees (VARs) since the 2019 season. VARs are used to assist the referee in making decisions on goals, penalties, and direct red cards.

article:
Oppenheimer (film)

Oppenheimer is a 2023 biographical drama film written and directed by Christopher Nolan. The film is a dramatized account of the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the director of the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb during World War II.

# Plot

The film follows Oppenheimer's journey from his early days as a physicist to his appointment as the director of the Manhattan Project. It explores his complex relationships with his colleagues, including Enrico Fermi, Ernest Lawrence, and Edward Teller, as well as his personal struggles with anxiety and depression. The film also delves into the moral implications of developing the atomic bomb and the devastating consequences of its use on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

# Cast

The film boasts an ensemble cast, including:

* Cillian Murphy as J. Robert Oppenheimer
* Emily Blunt as Katherine "Kitty" Oppenheimer
* Matt Damon as Leslie Groves
* Robert Downey Jr. as Lewis Strauss
* Florence Pugh as Jean Tatlock
* Rami Malek as Lyndon B. Johnson
* Benny Safdie as Edward Teller
* Josh Hartnett as Ernest Lawrence
* Dane DeHaan as Kenneth Nichols
* Alden Ehrenreich as unknown

# Production

## Development

Christopher Nolan had been fascinated by Oppenheimer's story for many years and had been researching his life and work since the early 2000s. Nolan wrote the screenplay for Oppenheimer in 2015, but he put the project on hold to focus on other films, including Dunkirk and Tenet. In 2020, Nolan returned to the project and began working with Syncopy Inc. and Atlas Entertainment to develop the film.

## Writing

Nolan's screenplay for Oppenheimer is based on several books about the physicist's life, including American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer by Kai Bird and Martin J. Sherwin. Nolan also drew inspiration from Oppenheimer's own writings and interviews. The screenplay explores Oppenheimer's complex personality and his struggles with the moral implications of his work.

## Casting

Casting for Oppenheimer began in 2020, with Cillian Murphy being the first actor to be cast in the title role. Emily Blunt was cast as Oppenheimer's wife, Katherine, in 2021, followed by Matt Damon as Leslie Groves and Robert Downey Jr. as Lewis Strauss. The rest of the cast was announced throughout 2022.

## Filming

Principal photography for Oppenheimer began in February 2022 and lasted for several months. The film was shot on location in various places, including New Mexico, California, and New York. Nolan worked with his longtime collaborator, cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema, to capture the film's complex and nuanced visuals.

## Post-production

Post-production for Oppenheimer began in the summer of 2022 and lasted for several months. Nolan worked with his editor, Jennifer Lame, to assemble the film's complex narrative. The film's visual effects were created by a team of artists led by Andrew Jackson.

# Music

The score for Oppenheimer was composed by Ludwig Göransson, who had previously worked with Nolan on Tenet. Göransson's score is a complex and nuanced blend of orchestral and choral music, reflecting the film's themes of science, morality, and humanity.

# Marketing

The marketing campaign for Oppenheimer began in the summer of 2022, with the release of a teaser trailer. The trailer was widely praised for its haunting and atmospheric visuals, which reflected the film's complex and nuanced tone. The full trailer was released in the fall of 2022, followed by a series of promotional posters and stills.

# Release

## Theatrical

Oppenheimer was released in theaters on July 21, 2023. The film was distributed by Universal Pictures and was released in various formats, including IMAX and Dolby Cinema.

### Classifications and censorship

Oppenheimer was rated R by the Motion Picture Association of America for its language, violence, and some suggestive content. The film was also classified as 15 by the British Board of Film Classification for its strong language, violence, and some sex references.

## Home media

Oppenheimer was released on digital platforms in September 2023, followed by a Blu-ray and DVD release in October 2023. The home media release included a series of bonus features, including a behind-the-scenes documentary and a commentary track by Christopher Nolan.

# Reception

## Box office

### United States and Canada

Oppenheimer was a commercial success in the United States and Canada, grossing over $100 million in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over $300 million in the United States and Canada, making it one of the highest-grossing films of 2023.

### Japan

Oppenheimer was also a commercial success in Japan, grossing over $20 million in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over $50 million in Japan, making it one of the highest-grossing foreign films of 2023.

### Other territories

Oppenheimer was a commercial success in other territories, grossing over $200 million in the United Kingdom, Australia, and other countries. The film went on to gross over $500 million worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing films of 2023.

## Critical response

Oppenheimer received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising its complex and nuanced portrayal of J. Robert Oppenheimer's life and work. The film's performances, direction, and score were also widely praised. The film holds a 95% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising its thought-provoking and emotionally resonant themes.

## Influence on legislation

Oppenheimer's portrayal of the atomic bomb's devastating consequences led to renewed calls for disarmament and nuclear non-proliferation. The film's release coincided with a series of international summits on nuclear disarmament, and many world leaders cited the film as an inspiration for their efforts to reduce the global nuclear arsenal.

# Accuracy and omissions

Oppenheimer has been praised for its historical accuracy and attention to detail. However, some critics have noted that the film omits certain aspects of Oppenheimer's life and work, including his relationships with other scientists and his involvement in the development of the hydrogen bomb.

# Accolades

Oppenheimer won several awards and nominations, including:

* Academy Award for Best Picture
* Academy Award for Best Director (Christopher Nolan)
* Academy Award for Best Actor (Cillian Murphy)
* Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama
* Golden Globe Award for Best Director (Christopher Nolan)
* Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama (Cillian Murphy)

* Manhattan Project
* Atomic bomb
* Nuclear disarmament

This article is a comprehensive summary of the film Oppenheimer. It provides an overview of the film's plot, production, and reception, as well as its historical accuracy and influence on legislation.

# References

This article does not include any references or citations. However, it is based on a wide range of sources, including books, articles, and interviews about J. Robert Oppenheimer and the film Oppenheimer.

2023 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament

The 2023 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament was a college baseball tournament held in the United States at the end of the 2023 NCAA Division I baseball season. The tournament was held from May 31 to June 26, 2023, and featured 64 college baseball teams from across the country.

# Tournament procedure

The tournament followed the same format as previous years. The 64 teams were divided into 16 regionals of four teams each, with the winner of each regional advancing to the Super Regionals. The Super Regionals were played as a best-of-three series, with the winner advancing to the Men's College World Series (MCWS) in Omaha, Nebraska. The MCWS was also played as a double-elimination tournament, with the winner advancing to the championship series.

# National seeds

The national seeds for the tournament were announced on May 29, 2023. The top eight seeds were:

5. Clemson

8. Oregon State

# Schedule and venues

article:
Federal Prosecution of Donald Trump (Classified Documents Case)

The federal prosecution of Donald Trump regarding the handling of classified documents is an ongoing legal case in the United States. The case involves allegations that Trump, the 45th President of the United States, mishandled classified documents after leaving office in January 2021. The investigation and subsequent indictment have been the subject of significant media attention and public interest.

#Background

In February 2022, the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) requested that the Department of Justice (DOJ) investigate Trump's handling of presidential records, including classified documents. The request was made after NARA discovered that Trump had taken a large number of documents with him when he left office, including some that were marked as classified.

In April 2022, the DOJ launched an investigation into Trump's handling of the documents, which was led by the FBI. The investigation involved a search of Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida, where many of the documents were found. The search was conducted on August 8, 2022, and resulted in the recovery of over 11,000 documents, including more than 100 that were marked as classified.

#Indictments and Arraignments

##Original Indictment

On June 8, 2023, a federal grand jury in the Southern District of Florida indicted Trump on charges related to his handling of classified documents. The indictment alleged that Trump had willfully retained national defense information, concealed documents, and obstructed justice. The indictment also named two of Trump's aides, Waltine "Walt" Nauta and Carlos De Oliveira, as co-defendants.

##Superseding Indictment

On July 18, 2023, a superseding indictment was filed, which added new charges against Trump, Nauta, and De Oliveira. The superseding indictment alleged that Trump had tampered with witnesses and attempted to intimidate witnesses.

##Assignment of District Judge

The case was assigned to Judge Aileen Cannon, a federal district judge in the Southern District of Florida. Judge Cannon was appointed to the bench by Trump in 2020.

##Arraignments

###Trump

Trump's arraignment was held on June 13, 2023, at the federal courthouse in Miami, Florida. Trump pleaded not guilty to the charges and was released on his own recognizance.

###Nauta

Nauta's arraignment was held on June 15, 2023, at the federal courthouse in Miami, Florida. Nauta pleaded not guilty to the charges and was released on his own recognizance.

###De Oliveira

De Oliveira's arraignment was held on June 16, 2023, at the federal courthouse in Miami, Florida. De Oliveira pleaded not guilty to the charges and was released on his own recognizance.

#Pretrial Proceedings

##2023

In the months following the indictment, the parties engaged in pretrial proceedings, including the exchange of discovery materials and the filing of motions. Trump's lawyers filed a motion to dismiss the indictment, which was denied by Judge Cannon.

##2024

In January 2024, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to indefinitely delay the trial, citing the upcoming presidential election and the need for Trump to focus on his campaign. The motion was opposed by the government, which argued that the trial should proceed as scheduled.

###Trump's Request to Indefinitely Delay Trial

On January 10, 2024, Judge Cannon denied Trump's motion to indefinitely delay the trial. Judge Cannon ruled that the trial would proceed as scheduled, despite Trump's arguments that he needed to focus on his presidential campaign.

#Dismissal and Appeal

On March 15, 2024, Judge Cannon dismissed the indictment against Trump, Nauta, and De Oliveira. The dismissal was based on Judge Cannon's ruling that the government had failed to prove that Trump had willfully retained national defense information.

The government appealed the dismissal to the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeal is ongoing.

#Response

##To Indictment

###Trump

Trump responded to the indictment by denying any wrongdoing and accusing the government of engaging in a "witch hunt." Trump also claimed that the indictment was an attempt to prevent him from running for president in 2024.

###Other Republicans

Many other Republicans, including some of Trump's allies, responded to the indictment by defending Trump and attacking the government. Some Republicans argued that the indictment was an attempt to interfere with the 2024 presidential election.

###Democrats

Many Democrats responded to the indictment by welcoming the news and praising the government for taking action against Trump. Some Democrats argued that the indictment was long overdue and that Trump had finally been held accountable for his actions.

##To Dismissal

###Trump

Trump responded to the dismissal of the indictment by celebrating the news and claiming that he had been vindicated. Trump also accused the government of engaging in a "witch hunt" and claimed that the dismissal was a victory for his supporters.

###Other Republicans

Many other Republicans responded to the dismissal by praising Judge Cannon and attacking the government. Some Republicans argued that the dismissal was a victory for Trump and a defeat for the "deep state."

###Democrats

Many Democrats responded to the dismissal by criticizing Judge Cannon and attacking Trump. Some Democrats argued that the dismissal was a miscarriage of justice and that Trump had been let off the hook.

Jimmy Buffett
================

Jimmy Buffett is a renowned American singer, songwriter, musician, and author, best known for his island-inspired music and laid-back, beach-bum persona. With a career spanning over five decades, Buffett has become a beloved figure in the music industry, entertaining millions of fans worldwide with his unique blend of country, rock, folk, and tropical music.

Early Life
-----------

James William Buffett was born on December 25, 1946, in Pascagoula, Mississippi, to James Delaney Buffett Jr. and Mary Loriane Peets Buffett. He grew up in Mobile, Alabama, where he developed a passion for music at an early age. Buffett's father was a naval officer, and the family moved frequently during his childhood, eventually settling in Mobile. He attended the University of Southern Mississippi, where he studied history and graduated in 1969.

Music Career
------------

Buffett's music career began in the late 1960s, when he started playing in local bands in Mobile and later in Nashville, Tennessee. He released his first album, "Down to Earth," in 1970, but it was his 1974 album "Living and Dying in 3/4 Time" that brought him his first taste of success. The album included the hit single "Come Monday," which reached the top 30 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

### Musical Style

Buffett's music is characterized by its laid-back, tropical vibe, often incorporating elements of country, rock, folk, and calypso. His songs often tell stories of love, heartache, and the carefree island lifestyle, which have become synonymous with his brand. Buffett's distinctive vocal style, which blends a smooth, raspy tone with a hint of Southern drawl, has become instantly recognizable to fans.

### Musical Legacy

Throughout his career, Buffett has released over 30 studio albums, many of which have been certified gold or platinum by the RIAA. He has had numerous chart-topping singles, including "Margaritaville," "Fins," and "Cheeseburger in Paradise." His music has been widely influential, inspiring a generation of singer-songwriters and bands, including Zac Brown Band, Kenny Chesney, and Alan Jackson.

### "Parrot Head" Fans

Buffett's devoted fan base, known as "Parrot Heads," has been a key factor in his enduring success. The Parrot Heads are a community of fans who share a passion for Buffett's music and the island lifestyle. They have created their own culture, with fan clubs, festivals, and charity events, all centered around Buffett's music.

Writing
-------

In addition to his music, Buffett is a prolific writer. He has written several best-selling novels, including "Tales from Margaritaville" and "Where Is Joe Merchant?" He has also written several non-fiction books, including "The Jolly Mon" and "A Pirate Looks at Fifty." Buffett's writing often reflects his love of the ocean and the island lifestyle, and his stories are often infused with humor and wit.

Film and Television
--------------------

Buffett has made numerous appearances in film and television, often playing himself or making cameo appearances.

### Soundtracks

Buffett has contributed to several film soundtracks, including "Fast Times at Ridgemont High," "Cocktail," and "The Big Blue." His music has been featured in numerous television shows, including "The Simpsons," "Friends," and "Saturday Night Live."

### Cameo Appearances

Buffett has made cameo appearances in several films, including "Cocktail," "From the Earth to the Moon," and "The Reef." He has also appeared in several television shows, including "The Simpsons," "Friends," and "Hawaii Five-0."

Theatre
------

Business Ventures

### Restaurants

### Record Labels

### Beer

### Casinos

### Sports

### Video Games

### Cannabis

### Berkshire Hathaway

Charity Work
------------

Buffett has been involved in several charitable efforts throughout his career.

### Environmental Conservation

Buffett has been a long-time supporter of environmental conservation, particularly in the area of ocean conservation. He has worked with several organizations, including the Surfrider Foundation and the Ocean Conservancy.

### Charity Performances

Buffett has performed at numerous charity events, including the annual Bridge School Benefit and the Hurricane Katrina relief concert.

### Disaster Relief

Personal Life

article:
Open-source video game
======================

An open-source video game is a type of video game that is released under a license that allows users to view, modify, and distribute the game's source code. This approach to game development has been gaining popularity over the years, with many developers embracing the open-source model as a way to create high-quality games while fostering a sense of community and collaboration.

Definition and differentiation
-----------------------------

Open-source video games are typically defined as games that are released under a license that allows users to access and modify the game's source code. This differentiates them from proprietary games, which are typically developed and published by a single company and are not freely available for modification or distribution.

Open-source games can be further distinguished from free-to-play games, which are games that are available at no cost but may still be proprietary and subject to certain restrictions. Additionally, open-source games are often distinct from freeware games, which are games that are available at no cost but may not necessarily be open-source.

Background
----------

The concept of open-source game development has its roots in the early days of computing, when software was often shared and modified freely. However, with the rise of the commercial game industry, game development became increasingly proprietary, with companies seeking to protect their intellectual property and maintain control over their games.

In recent years, however, there has been a growing trend towards open-source game development, driven in part by the success of open-source software projects such as Linux and Apache. Many developers have come to see the benefits of open-source development, including the ability to collaborate with others, to share knowledge and expertise, and to create high-quality software that is freely available to all.

History
-------

### Beginnings and early games

The history of open-source video games stretches back to the early days of computing, when games were often developed and shared by hobbyists and enthusiasts. One of the earliest examples of an open-source game is the 1970s-era game "Colossal Cave Adventure," which was developed by a group of students at Stanford University and later released under an open-source license.

Other early examples of open-source games include the 1980s-era games "NetHack" and "Larn," which were both developed by groups of enthusiasts and released under open-source licenses. These games were often simple text-based adventures, but they laid the groundwork for later open-source game development.

### 3D games and source releases

In the 1990s, the development of 3D graphics capabilities led to the creation of more complex and sophisticated games. One of the earliest examples of an open-source 3D game is the 1999 game "Quake," which was developed by id Software and later released under an open-source license.

The release of Quake's source code marked a significant milestone in the history of open-source game development, as it provided developers with access to a high-quality 3D game engine that could be modified and extended. Other companies, such as Epic Games and Valve Corporation, followed id Software's lead and released their own game engines under open-source licenses.

### Rise in popularity and diversity

In the 2000s, open-source game development began to gain popularity, as more developers became interested in the model and more games were released under open-source licenses. This led to a proliferation of open-source games across a wide range of genres, including first-person shooters, strategy games, and role-playing games.

One of the most notable examples of an open-source game from this period is the 2004 game "Battle for Wesnoth," a turn-based strategy game that was developed by a team of volunteers and released under an open-source license. Wesnoth has since become one of the most popular open-source games of all time, with a dedicated community of players and developers.

### Greater organization

In recent years, open-source game development has become more organized, with the establishment of formal projects and communities. One of the most notable examples is the Open Source Game Alliance, which was founded in 2013 to promote open-source game development and provide resources and support to developers.

Other organizations, such as the Linux Game Consortium and the Open Source Game Foundation, have also been established to support open-source game development. These organizations provide a range of services, including hosting, documentation, and community management, to help developers create and distribute open-source games.

### Hubs and development teams

In addition to formal organizations, open-source game development has also been facilitated by the establishment of online hubs and development teams. One of the most notable examples is the GitHub platform, which provides a range of tools and services for developers to collaborate on open-source projects.

Other platforms, such as GitLab and Bitbucket, also provide similar services, and have become popular hubs for open-source game development. Additionally, online communities such as Reddit's r/gamedev and r/opensourcedev have also become important hubs for developers to share knowledge, resources, and expertise.

2022 Korea Masters

The 2022 Korea Masters was a badminton tournament that took place at the Gwangju Women's University Stadium in Gwangju, South Korea, from April 12 to 17, 2022. The tournament was part of the 2022 BWF World Tour and was classified as a Super 300 event.

# Tournament

## Venue

The tournament was held at the Gwangju Women's University Stadium in Gwangju, South Korea. The stadium has a seating capacity of 10,000 and has hosted several international badminton tournaments in the past.

## Point distribution

The 2022 Korea Masters was a Super 300 event, which means that the winners of the tournament received 7,000 ranking points. The point distribution for the tournament was as follows:

* Winner: 7,000 points
* Runner-up: 5,950 points
* Semi-finalist: 4,900 points
* Quarter-finalist: 3,850 points
* Round of 16: 2,800 points
* Round of 32: 1,750 points
* Round of 64: 850 points

## Prize pool

The total prize pool for the 2022 Korea Masters was $250,000.

# Men's singles

## Finals

The final match of the men's singles event was played between Kanta Tsuneyama and Ng Ka Long. Kanta Tsuneyama won the match 21-19, 21-17.
